comments.commentBody: Very well done. The scenery is exotic and often magnificent, the acting is excellent (especially Sturgess and Harris). I found it generally believeable and a heroic testament to courage and willpower. Like Dahrgis, I kept wondering when they would make a move on the girl, but they didn't. And I could believe that as well. My only problem was with the way the film ended; somewhat silly and not  believable (He was incapable of contacting his wife for 50 years?  They had no phone service to Poland?).

It was gripping, entertaining and worth the money spent.

Chris Pine did well for himself. Denzel is as good as it gets. He & Tony seem to have hit the right combo and lot of good stuff is delivered to movie buffs.

Though the whole movie was gripping, what stands out is background music. It gave an ordinary looking scene a grip and thrill.

Even when I began as a seasonal ranger and guide at Mammoth Cave National Park, Kentucky, way back in 1969 (yes, about when Daniel Boone was still roaming Kentucky), the underground Echo River trip had already been discontinued, as it was 'too popular.' To this day that explanation seems a bit strange, but a senior guide led us guides on the Echo River trip one summer night, and of course I wanted to see 'Sanctum.' The newspaper ads say 'The only way out is down,' and unfortunately this movie is a downer.

Were all the extreme profanity excised, this film would probably be a live-action short. And that, as they say, was the good news. Virtually everyone is nasty, if not downright evil, and I wouldn't count on too many of these cave explorers surviving. Even the supposedly developing father-son relationship, Frank and Josh, could have been done much better.

Probably my own top cave experience was in the summer of 1969 when, to quote the plaque left there by one of my female naturalist friends, on such and such date a party of naturalists (Worm and Bagworm) and ranger (Tiger, yours truly) 'made the perilous ascent of the Corkscrew.' As for 'Sanctum,' the early air view of the huge sinkhole that is the cave's entrance was impressive. Otherwise, a female character's 'What could possibly go wrong?' is a precursor to just about everything going wrong in this nasty movie.

Oscar-nominated on 01/25/11 for Best Animated Feature, this gentle, bittersweet tale showcases simple pleasures, basic kindnesses, and family in its various forms. Nine years after this movie's 1959 beginning, I also took the train from Paris to the coast, a ferry across the English Channel (no 'Chunnel' then) to the white cliffs, and another train to London. Aging conjurer Monsieur Tatischeff always seeks another venue for his old-style magic act, with most people preferring the new rock 'n' roll. In one early scene the descending curtain hits the tall Tatischeff as he bows. At an opera, Tatischeff gets to do his act literally after the fat lady sings.

Post-London, Tatischeff takes train, boat, taxi, and another boat to a remote Scottish island, where he performs at a pub and guesthouse. There late teenaged chambermaid Alice believes that his magic is real. When Tatischeff leaves the island for Edinburgh, and Alice turns up as a stowaway on the ferry, sans ticket, the conjurer conjures up a ticket for her. In Edinburgh they take up strictly platonic residence at Little Joe Hotel. Alice has the bedroom (Tatischeff sleeps on the sofa) and becomes his surrogate daughter. Tatischeff and Alice are kind to each other. She keeps house and often feeds such other hotel residents as an almost suicidal clown and a drunk ventriloquist. He takes other jobs to supplement his income and to buy her red shoes, a white coat, and then white heels that she admires.

However, Alice meets a nice young man her own age, and we sense that the Tatischeff and Alice 'family' won't last forever. I didn't care that much for the ending, but it did provide my title. In essence, we should all enjoy life's simple pleasures and our own family, however defined, while we are still here.

comments.commentTitle: The Puerile Hubris of an Imperial President
comments.commentBody:
Quoted from the A.O. Scott review: "We need to keep fighting about the recent past because its legacy is still with us, of course, but also, perhaps, to distract us from the equally quarrelsome present."

Yes and no. Of course the memory is still with us, although hardly a 'legacy' yet, and that because, for me, it doesn't distract as much as refocus our querulousness on the 'quarrelsome present'. I liked M. Kaufman's 'take' on it and agree with his high opinion. It was a fascinating film. Ironically it does insist that we pay attention. Too bad we didn't pay attention better in 2000. [4.2/5.0]

The movie seems a bit contrived, probbaly because of the focus slightly tilted towards family in-fights. The most interesting thing for me was rendering of how nicely things are "dressed up" for public consumption. The depiction how information being hijacked by current political agenda is brilliant.

I've yet to see the film, but the review was great: not just re. the film, but also insight into the art and craft of cinematography, and the psychology of how the mysterious thing happens when "me" goes to "we."
The stupid software requires a "rating" first...., so, in anticipation!
She has issues with King's Speech but adores Black Knight. 'nuf said!

comments.commentTitle: You don't have to be small minded to take exception
comments.commentBody: This is a well done and interesting film, and I applaud it.  However, I do think the film makers are "Hollywood liberals," because they fail to address, and answer, the central question - why does the suspect's cell phone show contact with a known terrorist?  Did our government make up that evidence?  Apparently not.  Did the suspect explain it (before he was "leaned on"?)  No.  There was some vague notion of having lost the phone or loaned it to someone, but there was no science or word of dialogue that dealt with it.  As far as the idea that this suspect was a great, regular guy and the "same guy" he was in college - well just how would a real covert terrorist act?  I'd like to see Hollywood make a movie about detainees who, once release, returned to terrorism, thus proving their guilt.  You know, just to balance matters.  Having said all that, this is an intelligent and well acted movie and well worth seeing.

Las Vegas would be my choice even if gambling and night life weren't there.  There are more federal and state lands attractions nearby than any city I can think of: two National Conservation Areas and a third in the works on Bureau of Land Management land; two National Recreation Areas on National Park and National Forest Service land; about 14 dedicated Wilderness Areas on national forest, national park, and Bureau of Land Management land and more being worked on for the future; the largest and most spectacular state park in Nevada; the largest National Wildlife Range in the lower 48 states; outdoor activities from altitudes of 500 feet (think winter hiking) to 12,000 feet (think summer hiking); downhill and X-country skiing in winter in the national forest and water skiing in summer on perhaps the largest scenic reservoir in the nation; abundant back country roads to explore with 4WD; the city as a hub where spokes lead outward to further wonders such as the Grand Canyon, Sierra Nevada, and the gorgeous national parks of Southern Utah; three or four good guide books available telling one how to reach and enjoy these wonders.

I visited Marine plaza last week for 3 day business trip. the hotel has an amazing sea view. renovated bedding program with 32 inch lcd tv in the room. great shower and lovely restaurants with midnight buffet, since we came back late night after watching a movie. Staff attitude is very professional and courteous. loved Geoffreys the irish pub. www.hotelmarineplaza.com
I stayed at Hotel Aubrey in Santiago a few months ago. It's an absolutely beautiful place, set partly in a restored historic mansion. Very unique!

Always good to see other people's recommendations, but I don't see mention of Antiche Carampane, Vino da Gigio, Fiaschetteria Toscana, Testiere,  Anice Stellato or Da Marisa, for instance, each in it's way special. Either way,if you go to Venice, you must, must, MUST buy Michela Scibilia's delightful'Osterie e Dintorni'. A personal view, maybe, but unpretentious and accurate it will spare you all those expensive tourist rip-offs your hotel may try to send you to (if it's not in there, maybe don't bother)and is worth its weight in gold. Simply one of the best restaurant guides to ANY city (ask any one who's bought one!)....

comments.commentTitle: When you need a night in!
comments.commentBody:
There is a website run by Americans called www.buenosairesdelivery.com that has all the restaurants that deliver to your hotel or apartment and allows you to order online.

The Buenos Aires nightlife is crazy and sometimes you need a night in. There are a ton of good restaurants in the Palermo area! We loved Poke Restaurant and Peru Deli (interestingly enough, the Peruvian food was better than in Peru!!)

Definitely worth a visit, a very talented silversmith who will work to create unique Jewish silver work for you. Also worth looking at his fellow artists at work in the aptly named "Jerusalem House of Quality"

I would fully agree with Gabe Doyle as quoted in #32. Languages have to change with times and the understanding of the word 'data' today is very different from how it was understood before the invention of data storage & processing devices. Today it means not just a collection of information, facts etc. but that collection being available at a single place and in a convenient format. Therefore. data is sounds much more logical than data are.

Hans #34. The population distribution would definitely be not uniform. There will be several things affecting there such as weather & climate factors, religion & days considered auspicious, holidays etc. In India for example, disproportionate marriages occur in February and August considered to be auspicious and with a lot of couples planning for children immediately, a lot of births should happen in December & May.
Ace for pal...I still don't get it?  Can anyone help me out?

comments.commentTitle: Luxury close to the Champs Elysees
comments.commentBody:
The hotel Concortel is very luxurious. It's just a 3 star, but the deluxe rooms & the suites are very spacious and elegant. The style of the decoration is sober, but very classy. And the service is excellent, thanks to the professionalism and the kindness of the staff!
The hotel is close to the Galeries Lafayette and a few minutes from the Champs Elysees.
http://www.concortel-paris-hotel.com/

We had dinner at Chanticlair this past week and were very impressed.  It is a small, informal restaurant in the Marina area. The food was excellent, highlited by the sole, mushroom/escargot soup and their signature Innommable dessert.  The wine selection was good and the service friendly and attentive.  If you want great French cuisine in Marigot, Le Chanteclair will not disappoint you.
What no special category for the Irish?  There used to be signs "Irish need not apply".  Apparently they were not considered white.

Ellie’s Koloa House was so reasonably priced for two couples that frankly we wondered what we would find.  What we found was a clean and charming little house with very satisfactory bedrooms, a well-equipped kitchen, a comfortable living room, a spacious shaded patio, and a beautiful garden.  We did have to share the one full bathroom; the second one is a shower and toilet off the patio – convenient for coming back from the beach.  The location was a plus for us: we liked being in a quiet residential neighborhood away from the glitz of Poipu but only a ten-minute drive away at the peaceful 25mph speed limit. Parking near the beach was never a problem. The house is also walking distance to Old Koloa Town, which has its own charm and  convenient shops.  At one of these, the Koloa Fish Market, we bought wonderfully fresh opa (moonfish) steaks to bring back to the house for some of the best eating of our week.  We also got, for $8, excellent plate lunches, each featuring two good pieces of excellent fish.  These we brought back to the house and enjoyed on the patio.  Our hostess, Ellie Knopf, was helpful and attentive without being intrusive.  She made some excellent recommendations, including the Casa d’Amici restaurant, where we had one of our best dinners ever.  We’re recommending Ellie’s Koloa House to friends and family.

I have never really been an aerosmith fan, but after watching Steven Tyler, I think maybe I have to reconsider.  He seems genuinely in love with music and reacts to a good performance, or even the hint of it, with emotion.  I admit I was skeptical when I heard he was joining the cast, but really his musical taste and kindness have given new class to this show.

my partner & I will be visiting BA in May to celebrate our anniversary and want your best recommendations for the following:  drinking, lunch/dinner (stylish venue & local cool crowd, non touristy - excellent food and wine list), music/venues (fav bands - Nick Cave & the bad seeds, Radiohead, Beck, Black Keys - anything loud and indi also happy with anything different).  Most likely staying in Palermo Soho unless a new cool area is recommended.  Any help would be appreciated.  Happy to help with any info on Sydney too.

I have tried out most of them and Lanny's is the best restaurant in the whole DFW area.  It is hard to determine what is the best asset: the food, the staff or the owner/chef.  If you are ever in the area or even close, it is definitely worth a visit.

A little historic building tucked away in a bustling city serving a beautiful mix of seasonal NZ produce with a classic bistro style.
Delicious food and fantastic friendly service.
